Award.AwardTitle: Math Plus One: A Scholarship Program Enabling Young Mathematicians to Achieve Their Academic and Career Goals Through Dual Majors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
La Salle University's Math Plus One (M+1) program will recruit students into mathematics through a focus on career preparation, strong student support services, and scholarship funding that will make college more affordable. The M+1 program will recruit 16 students (two cohorts of 8) who will major in mathematics and one other related area, with an emphasis on the fields of computer science, economics, finance, and chemistry. M+1 graduates will have a competitive advantage when seeking post-graduate employment and will fill critical workforce needs in the Greater Philadelphia area.

La Salle will provide four years of scholarship assistance to each M+1 student. Students will participate in undergraduate research, attend regional and national conferences, complete internships, and receive career mentoring from members of the Mathematics Advisory Board. The Mathematics Advisory Board will consist of local business and educational leaders that, in addition to mentoring scholars, will guide and help shape the M+1 program. The goals of the M+1 program are to increase the enrollment of math majors, ensure a diversified math student population, provide strong support services to S-STEM recipients, and ensure that S-STEM students graduate in a timely manner and obtain positions in their fields after graduation. Recruitment efforts will target students underrepresented in the field, particularly women and minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Math Plus One program implemented in the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at La Salle University as a result of this S-STEM award facilitated the recruitment, retention, and academic and professional success of a diverse group of talented STEM scholars, the majority of whom came from low-income families or were members of groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. This was accomplished by providing a total of 29 students more than $542,000 in scholarships, individualized faculty advising and mentorship, internships and career preparation, research and conference travel opportunities, and collaboration with each other and peers outside of the program.

A unique characteristic of the program was its emphasis on the power of mathematics in combination with another academic discipline. Most of the students in the program pursued majors in both mathematics and another area. These disciplines included computer science, chemistry, biology, economics, finance, and accounting. Both those who initially viewed mathematics as their main area of pursuit and those who originally found themselves more interested in a related applied area benefited tremendously from the complementary nature of their majors.

Nearly all project goals were met or exceeded. The average number of Mathematics majors at La Salle increased by over 20% from pre-implementation to post-implementation of the grant. Over 60% of the students funded through the program fell into one or more categories whose members have historically encountered barriers to entry and persistence in STEM majors and careers. Nearly 35% came from families with annual incomes qualifying for Federal Pell Grants, and over 35% were from racial or ethnic minority groups. We fell short of our goal of funding at least as many women as men, but this was largely due to the financial ineligibility of several qualified women; when considering all of our mathematics majors, females comprise over 40% of our population as of the close of the grant.

All but two of the 29 students funded through the grant have graduated (9) or are on pace to graduate (16) from La Salle in at most five years. Of the nine graduates, within one month of graduation, five had found high-quality positions in their chosen fields and the other four had accepted graduate school offers. Among them are one actuary, three graduates employed in the computing field, and one accountant. Of those continuing their studies, three have entered Ph.D. programs in STEM fields with assistantships, and one has entered law school. Prospects for this year's graduates are similarly encouraging. These outcomes were facilitated by several components of the grant. Frequent individualized advising interactions enabled faculty to gain awareness of students' interests and strengths, which led to particularly relevant internships and research experiences. All but one of the nine graduates participated in an internship or research opportunity, and these activities have also been undertaken by or are planned for the continuing students. Several research experiences led to acceptances to share work externally in the form of papers, talks, or posters, with both research funding and conference travel support facilitated by the grant. Students also participated in an annual half-day workshop on career preparation and a one-credit course on preparing specifically for careers in technology, both offered by the department; worked with staff in the campus career center; and attended presentations by alumni and others. Many served as departmental tutors and took on leadership roles or participated frequently in the mathematics club. All of these co-curricular experiences were bolstered further by the fact that these students acquired knowledge and skills in not just one area but in both mathematics and an additional complementary field of interest. This combination of rigorous mathematical training plus an emphasis on practical applications allowed them to further distinguish themselves from their peers as well-prepared problem-solvers and critical thinkers.

We project that the positive outcomes for the students involved, established culture and programming in the department, and strengthened relationships with colleagues in complementary disciplines due to the grant will have a lasting impact. We expect that they will enable us to sustain a similar level of enrollment and success in the major and to increase the percentages of students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM. The increased diversity in the department as a result of the grant has benefited students and faculty alike by filling our community with a wider array of perspectives, backgrounds, and interests. Coordination and collaboration with faculty in other departments has increased our mutual understanding and has paved the way for future joint work and the continuation of successful dual majors. In addition, while La Salle draws students from a large number of states as well as internationally, the majority are from Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Another lasting effect of the program is therefore expected to be a steady infusion of graduates into the Greater Philadelphia regional STEM workforce.
